content.webTitle: Art historian claims Gainsborough painting actually by artist’s nephew

fields.headline: Art historian claims Gainsborough painting actually by artist’s nephew
fields.bodyText: One of the nation’s treasured paintings by Thomas Gainsborough is not by the 18th-century master but probably the work of the artist’s nephew, a leading art historian maintains. Miss Brummell depicts a young girl cradling a cat in a wooded landscape and is one of a group of old master paintings at Kenwood House, a handsome stately home in Hampstead, London, now in the care of English Heritage. Hugh Belsey, a world authority on Gainsborough, said that the painting will be among works that he will list as “rejected” in his catalogue raisonné, a definitive study of the artist’s portraits, to be published by Yale University Press next year. Belsey believes that the Brummell portrait was painted by the artist’s nephew and sole studio assistant, Gainsborough Dupont. Belsey, a senior research fellow at the Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art, a UK research centre linked to Yale University, is a former director of Gainsborough House, the museum and art gallery at the artist’s birthplace in Sudbury, Suffolk, where he helped to build up one of the world’s largest collections of the artist’s work. Commenting on works that he has chosen to demote, Belsey said: “There are some quite well-known ones, I’m afraid.” Documentary evidence relating to Gainsborough’s commissions is thought to have been destroyed shortly after his death, creating a verification problem for future art historians. The Brummell portrait was still clearly labelled as a Gainsborough last week at Kenwood House, where one guidebook states that the sitter “was aged about 10 in this portrait by Gainsborough”. But Belsey is certain the attribution is mistaken, believing that the most likely painter is Gainsborough Dupont, who was apprenticed to Gainsborough between 1772 and 1788. Dupont painted in Gainsborough’s style and George III was among his admirers. “It’s just not Gainsborough’s style. It’s too messy. It lacks confidence. The handling is rather scratchy in comparison with Gainsborough,” Belsey said. The draughtsmanship of the cat in the painting pales against that of a cat washing itself in a Gainsborough chalk drawing now in Amsterdam, he said, pointing out that the background landscape also lacks the brilliance of other paintings. He added that while “there doesn’t seem to be anyone who’s doubted it, I’ve always had my suspicions about it. It’s a very good Dupont. It’s his without any doubt at all.” The Brummell portrait, an oil on canvas measuring 30x25in (76x64cm), was bought in 1888 by the 1st Earl of Iveagh. It was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1928. English Heritage said: “We are always open to hearing new findings and look forward to seeing any new research.” Its experts have dated the painting to the early 1780s and suggested that it was commissioned when the sitter’s father, George “Beau” Brummell, the famous English dandy, bought an estate near Newbury in Berkshire. . Belsey’s Yale catalogue will feature 1,000 authentic Gainsborough portraits, including about 10 of dogs, which are “utterly wonderful”, he said. The last definitive study of Gainsborough’s works was published in 1958, and was undertaken by Professor Sir Ellis Waterhouse, a former director of the Barber Institute of Fine Arts in Birmingham. The new catalogue adds about 200 works that have emerged over decades. Other “rejects” include a painting in the Royal Albert Memorial Museum in Exeter. Belsey said: “It is a portrait of William Jackson, which I’ve told them endlessly is not by Gainsborough. It’s probably by Thomas Hickey. But they have resolutely decided to keep it on the wall as Gainsborough.” The Exeter museum told the Observer that it will now accept Belsey’s judgment about the William Jackson portrait. Nor does he support the Gainsborough attribution of a portrait of Captain Roberts in Floors Castle, Roxburghshire, the stately home in the Scottish Borders: “That’s by Dupont. It couldn’t be by Gainsborough because he’s shown in a captain’s uniform and he wasn’t made captain until 1795, seven years after Gainsborough died.” Among overseas public institutions, he discounts the portrait of Mrs Charles Hatchett in the Frick Collection, New York, which is described as “attributed to” Gainsborough. That, too, is Dupont, Belsey believes. Belsey said an incorrect attribution detracts from the genius of Gainsborough: “It blurs the image of his abilities.”
